Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Eddy Correlation and chamber measurements of benthic oxygen fluxes in permeable sediments
Award.AbstractNarration:
The project will investigate the measurement of oxygen flux across the sediment water interface using the eddy correlation technique, which is an in situ approach for continuous measurement. Obtaining such fluxes will increase the ability to measure accurately benthic oxygen fluxes in sediments. This project will further the development of the eddy correlation technique and compare these results with advection chambers and with the perfusion method, both of which are currently used, to validate the eddy correlation approach and show its broad applicability. A process-based mathematical model will also be developed and used, with the flux measurements and porewater data, to validate the technique and will also be used to interpret and synthesize the results. The scientific merit of this research is that oxygen fluxes are the main proxy for assessing carbon cycling rates in sediments and are used widely in carbon budget estimates. The project will therefore help improve such estimates by increasing the database on oxygen fluxes for permeable shelf sediments, and by providing an increased understanding of the controlling variables.

The project will develop an outreach program in conjunction with the Virginia Coast Reserve LTER, one of the locations of this project, which has an active outreach program to K-12 schools, with a strong impact on minority groups. The project will also involve graduate and undergraduate education.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Submerged permeable sandy sediments are found everywhere along our shore lines. Due to the porous structure of sands, current and wave motions can induce extensive exchange of water and water borne constituents between bottom water and the pore space in the upper sand layers. This exchange largely controls how organic matter is transported into the sand from the water above, how it is then broken down, and how the bi-products are released again.

Traditional underwater flux methods have difficulties capturing this exchange under natural field conditions and may therefore significantly bias the fluxes they produce. Because sands are found everywhere, this uncertainty affects carbon budget estimates on both local and global scales, and ultimately adds uncertainly to our model predictions of carbon cycling and global warming.

These potentially wide-reaching consequences were the foundation of this project that focused on improving our ability to measure, understand, and predict fluxes between the water column and sandy sediments. Both PIs have pioneered novel flux methods specifically for permeable sands, and by comparing results from parallel deployments of both approaches the project shed light on the conditions under which these methods produce trustworthy flux estimates. This effort also added valuable numbers to the sparsely populated global data base of fluxes for permeable sediments. In addition, detailed modeling of the transport of water borne constituents, and its interactions with inhomogeneous bottoms, improved our interpretations of measured flux data. Several graduate students were trained in the project which also hosted workshops for new users of state-of-the-art flux methods for permeable sediments. Finally, results were presented in numerous scientific publications and at special international conference sessions, including two chaired by the PIs. A good overview of results from this project is given on two websites developed within this project and hosted by the PIs institutions:

University of Virginia: http://faculty.virginia.edu/berg/

Florida State University: http://myweb.fsu.edu/mhuettel/Projects/NSF_Eddy.html
